title: Sklar Brothers: Where are the Ben-Guys?
text:
Sklar Brothers want to know: Where are the Ben-Guys? Jim Owczarski , jowczarski@enquirer.com 5:42 p.m. EDT October 16, 2015 Randy and Jason Sklar joined the Ben-Gals on Oct. 11 to film an NFL Network short for NFL Now. (Photo: Provided/NFL Now) 
The Cincinnati Bengals are awash in waves of popularity, with the players and coaches in demand for their time and likeness. Such are the spoils of victory. 
But sometimes, a question long unanswered needed to be asked – whether the team was undefeated, or winless. 
And the Sklar Brothers , Randy and Jason, were the ones to ask it. 
“Where are the Ben-Guys?” Randy asked last Sunday as they waited to run out onto the Paul Brown Stadium turf. 
Following their show at the Taft Theatre on Saturday, the comedy duo rolled over to PBS to hang out with the Ben-Gals, and see if they had what it took to be Ben-Guys. The Enquirer caught up with the pair during a break in filming, as they recorded the experience for the NFL Network’s “Trend Zone.” 
“You think about collegiate cheerleading – and we’re college football fans – there are tons of guys,” Randy said, an extra small Ben-Gals jacket fitting snugly over his clothes. “Where do they go?” 
“They have settle and move on in life and become presidents of the United States like George Bush,” Jason interjected. “They don’t get the glory.” 
They noted that the Baltimore Ravens have male cheerleaders, but that’s it. 
The Bengals' cheerleaders welcomed the Sklar brothers onto their team prior to the Seattle game on Oct. 11. (Photo: The Enquirer/Kareem Elgazzar) 
“What if you don’t live in Baltimore?” Randy asked. 
The brothers worked out with the Ben-Gals prior to the game against Seattle, warmed up and rehearsed routines they did not know in advance – in jeans. 
“It’s like your European cousin who comes to play pickup basketball, right, Jay?” Randy asked. 
“He’s like in dress socks, loafers and jeans and he throws the ball up on the roof and it gets stuck in there and it’s like, well, you can’t get it down for two years,” Jason said. “That’s what we’re like.”
